com:
Final Fantasy 7 Remake's combat system is a 9/10. It's so fucking fun. It's like the perfect blend of action and strategy. I feel like there's no way you can say the OG's combat is better without said opinion being 99.9% rooted in nostalgia. And btw, no, that isn't to say that the OGs turn-based ATB is bad. Just that the Remake's combat is superior. Now it isn't flawless though.

For example, trying to fight enemies that fly/float in the air is awkward/clunky as shit for anyone not Barret or Aerith. Luckily though, the Yuffie DLC has fixed that. It also just improved the combat even more in-general and made it a perfect 10/10. I'm so excited for how Red XIII, Vincent, and Cid is going to play in Rebirth. Honestly, it's combat should be the default for any future Final Fantasy or any JRPG that features action-oriented gameplay and a party in the future.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>620647948
VC2 and VC3 are PSP games, thus they both reuse maps. VC3 increase the number of maps, making it slightly more bearable.
VC2 requires a lot of grinding, and that's because the items you need to level up your troops or equipment has a random chance to drop; it's RNG. This is because the devs thought that, since it's a portable game, people would be playing it while on the bus or train, so players wouldn't mind sitting down for a couple of minutes grinding. There are new classes that don't make an appearance in VC4, and a couple are quite broken in this game. Gunners are shit at offense but a really good as assists or for defense, and Fencers are almost immune to bullets and can kill most enemies in 1-2 hits with their only weakness being low AP. Avan is the only character who can be any class, and thus can become the most broken character in the game.
VC3 doesn't have the RNG drops and is much better. There's a bit more variety in the maps, but there's a lot of reuse. Classes aren't as broken as they were in VC2.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>620651351
The only thing Valkyria Revolution has in common with VC is that Valkyria and Ragnite exist. It was made as a PS vita game and, graphically, it shows. Gameplay is a bit stiff. It's not a musou game as there's only one melee button. You can shoot and throw grenades, but magic exists in that game it magic can do both of those things except even better; more damage, less resources to upgrade, the game pauses while you (the player. This doesn't happen for the AI, both your allies and enemies) do them, etc. (I went through the entire game using two of the beginner magic attacks without upgrading them and the game was a cake walk. The only time I used melee was for a boss that required it and to refill my character's MP and for the final boss, who was also pretty easy). Only play it if you have a vita or (if on PS4) it's cheap and you've not nothing better to do.
Valkyria Chronicles Duel was a browser game that's now dead. I don't remember much of the gameplay other than base building shit, but I do remember that it reused the PSP's character models and stuff.
Those are the only two spinoff games that I remember.

I also forgot to mention but, just like with VC1 and VC4, the only hard missions in VC2 and VC3 are the bonus, post game missions and DLC missions (which are also post-game). You get some really neat unlockables from finishing them though, like strong equipment and, for VC3, new characters.

com:
If you don't play every single Armored Core game before VI comes out, you are a secondary bandwagon faggot contributing to the downfall of FromSoft. Yes, that includes Project Phantasma, as well as Frame Gride, Metal Wolf Chaos and Murakumo. All of these games are easy to acquire and emulate, and all it takes is 10-20 minutes to understand why this series is so beloved and sink hundreds of hours into them.

>https://cdromance.com/?s=armored+core (PS1, PS2 and PSP games)
>https://vimm.net/vault/PS3/A (PS3 games, all run well in RPCS3)

People who played Demon's Souls when it came out understood right away what Dark Souls improved on and what it left behind. Playing King's Field I-IV is necessary to see why Dark Souls 2 is a misunderstood masterpiece. You can clearly see the DNA of Shadow Tower and Echo Night in Bloodborne, and it has all but been confirmed that Sekiro is a spiritual successor to Tenchu.

You have plenty of time to immerse yourself in this franchise. I'm on Armored Core 2 right now, then I'm gonna replay the translated version of Formula Front International before hitting the other spin-offs. This isn't about elitism or gatekeeping, it's about context. You are guaranteed to see untold amounts of normalfags latching onto Armored Core in the coming months when they never gave a shit about it before.

Mecha has always been a vastly underrated genre, be it in games or anime. MechWarrior, Super Robot Wars, Gundam and Armored Core have been the flagbearers for this genre for nearly three decades now, but naming all of the important mecha anime out there would reach the post limit.

YOU OWE IT TO YOURSELF IF YOU LIKE SOULS GAMES.
